content.body: sideshowbarker: Is the https://github.com/w3c/mdn-spec-links project dead? It looks like it hasn't updated in two years, and now there are three specs listed in https://w3c.github.io/mdn-spec-links/SPECMAP.json whose files no longer exist in the repo.
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: Is the https://github.com/w3c/mdn-spec-links project dead? It looks like it hasn't updated in two years, and now there are three specs listed in https://w3c.github.io/mdn-spec-links/SPECMAP.json whose files no longer exist in the repo.

content.body: Dead
Essentially, yes
is there a replacement? otherwise I need to just remove the MDN-panel feature from bikeshed
Please go ahead and remove it.
There's no replacement
If I could get somebody to take over maintenance on it, that would be great
Or to make a replacement
But in the meantime, let's just rip it out
kk, i'm just gonna check with our internal mdn people first

annevk: I've updated the out-of-order streaming explainer after the discussion about prepend last WHATNOT... 
https://github.com/WICG/declarative-partial-updates/blob/main/patching-explainer.md#interleaved-patching
In short, I think we still need append/replace-children as methods to allow multiple patches to the same element accumulate, and doing that with comments would be messy
content.formatted_body:
annevk: I've updated the out-of-order streaming explainer after the discussion about prepend last WHATNOT...
https://github.com/WICG/declarative-partial-updates/blob/main/patching-explainer.md#interleaved-patching
In short, I think we still need append/replace-children as methods to allow multiple patches to the same element accumulate, and doing that with comments would be messy

content.body: Oh, maybe the checker is wrong? /me finds https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10532
from what I recall of that, I maintain that the checker is in fact not wrong
that is, the checker is flagging an actual ‚Äútable integrity‚Äù error

but that said, the message is just a warning; and if the table-integrity ‚Äúerror‚Äù isn‚Äôt causing any known actual problems for anybody¬†trying to use the information in the ‚Äî¬†in particular, not for AT users especially, but also, not resulting in an visual breakage¬†‚Äî then the right (pragmatic) thing to do it, just ignore it
and also in general, it may be time for us to no longer be treating all checker warnings as errors ‚Äî as far as the spec builds go
